text: Ex vivo activation of tumor-draining lymph node T cells reverses defects in signal transduction molecules .

The adoptive transfer of tumor-draining lymph node ( LN ) T cells activated ex vivo with anti-CD3 and <extra_id_0> interleukin 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) mediates the regression of the poorly immunogenic murine melanoma D5 .

The efficacy of the activated LN cells is augmented when the sensitizing tumor is a genetically modified variant ( designated D5G6 ) that secretes <extra_id_0> granulocyte/macrophage-colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
In contrast to anti-CD3 / <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - activated LN cells , adoptive transfer of freshly isolated tumor-draining LN T cells has no therapeutic activity .

To determine whether the acquisition of antitumor function during ex vivo activation is associated with modifications in signal transduction capacity , the protein tyrosine kinases <extra_id_0> p56lck <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p59fyn <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and proteins of the NF-kappaB family were analyzed in tumor-draining LN T cells .

text: In contrast , the cytoplasmic levels of <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Rel A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were normal in freshly isolated tumor-draining LN , as was nuclear kappaB DNA - binding activity induced by anti-CD3 mAb or phorbol myristate acetate .

text: Stimulation of activated LN cells with D5 tumor cells induced the nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB .

These findings indicate that the recovery of proteins mediating signal transduction through the T cell receptor / CD3 complex in LN T cells activated ex vivo was associated with the acquisition of antitumor function .
